posts.cooked:
Hello,
Signal does not install on Debian Linux as repository error is “repository does not exist”.
Can you please help regarding this.
You’ll need to include some details with the exact steps you are using to install the app and the full error output.

I am following the install instructions from Signal >> Download Signal for Linux install. There are 3 steps which you can see from that link and I have followed that list.
The exact error is:
E: Malformed line 2 in source list /etc/apt/sources.list.d/signal-xenial.list
E: The list of sources could not be read.
Nothing can proceed from there without signal tech support, can you help with this?

Further to my second reply:
I have just noticed that a random “q” was added to the file /etc/apt/sources.list.d/signal-xenial.list
I am uncertain where this “q” came from but after removing it, the repository no longer says that it can’t be accessed or is Malformed but when trying sudo apt install signal-desktop it says error:
E: Unable to locate package signal-desktop

ojcs1:

but when trying sudo apt install signal-desktop it says error:
E: Unable to locate package signal-desktop

Did you do sudo apt update before that? Otherwise, your system doesn’t know which packages are offered by this new package source you just added.
Yes, I did sudo apt update before & rebooted.

In the official guide line to install the desktop app is a mistake with a deprecated keyring. You will find the correct instruction for example here:

https://wiki.ubuntuusers.de/Signal_Desktop/

These instructions work for Debian as well as Ubuntu - I’ve used them for both distributions. Sorry for the link to a German website, but I’m from Germany.

P.S.: You need to have Curl installed.

afaik, it’s a while now that apt-key add is no longer part of the official description:

Signal Repo !NOT SIGNED!

b) I doubt that the majority of users have the Signal-Desktop-Key in “trusted.gpg”, because if you follow the official howto for installing Signal-Desktop (on Linux machines), apt-key add is missing.

I suggest you to go step by step from the beginning (without random "q" & co)
Also make sure you’re not trying to install Signal on a 32-bit platform or on ARM.

I am running 64 bit Debian on Raspberry Pi Gen 4.
I have followed the signal installation as shown on Signal >> Download Signal
However I have noticed 2 anomalies:

  1. A random letter “q” appeared in /etc/apt/sources.list.d/signal-xenial.list. Which I removed.
  2. When following the signal install instructions, the "signal-desktop-keyring.gpg was placed into the /home/USER/ Folder. I manually transferred the file “signal-desktop-keyring.gpg” into /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d Folder but when running sudo apt update and then sudo apt install signal-desktop, it still says Error “E: Unable to locate package signal-desktop”
In addition to my last past, I have since discovered that my Raspberry PI is an ARM Chip. Can we ask signal to place a note on the install instructions about this?

ojcs1:

Raspberry Pi Gen 4.

And there’s the problem, Raspberry Pi is ARM, as you seem to have realized.

ojcs1:

Can we ask signal to place a note on the install instructions about this?

I guess it’s potentially a bit unclear since the note only says it works on “64 bit Debian-based”, though if you pay attention to the commands being used you’ll see that it says arch=amd64, which is not ARM. It can’t hurt to ask them to be more specific though.

When following the signal install instructions, the "signal-desktop-keyring.gpg was placed into the /home/USER/ Folder

you are not the first to be irritated by this, see:

Dont store keyring in home directory Desktop Feature Requests
The “signal-desktop-keyring.gpg” is stored directly inside the home directory by an linux installation. In my opinion it is messy. Please store the keyring somewhere else, or hide it at least.

link_counts.title: Dont store keyring in home directory

posts.name: matt
posts.cooked:
hi, i have similar issue to the guy that initially asked this question, so decided to respond here, as opposed to open up new topic on signal install for linux.

it’s for a friend. i was able to install signal, on my linux mint, but she can’t for some reason.

the error messages she gets, after inputting the 3 commands listed on the website:

# NOTE: These instructions only work for 64-bit Debian-based
# Linux distributions such as Ubuntu, Mint etc.

# 1. Install our official public software signing key:
wget -O- https://updates.signal.org/desktop/apt/keys.asc | gpg --dearmor > signal-desktop-keyring.gpg;
cat signal-desktop-keyring.gpg | sudo tee /usr/share/keyrings/signal-desktop-keyring.gpg > /dev/null

# 2. Add our repository to your list of repositories:
echo 'deb [arch=amd64 signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/signal-desktop-keyring.gpg] https://updates.signal.org/desktop/apt xenial main' |\
  sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/signal-xenial.list

# 3. Update your package database and install Signal:
sudo apt update && sudo apt install signal-desktop

are, from her screenshots:
(aha, seems i can’t share attachments, as a new user? )

well, seems the 1st 2 commands went through ok.
but the 3rd (actually installing signal), seemed to have problems with the Repo… but it’s not clear from the cmd response, as she has a known problem with another repo on her computer.

would gladly share screenshot if i can.

appreciate any steps we can take to install signal on her linux mint.
thanks.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: can you please copy-paste the error you’re getting?

posts.name: matt
posts.cooked:
hi,
sorry about delay getting back. slipped my mind.
in the end, we figured out the issue. she needed to change the mirrors she had set up, as previous ones weren’t finding the relevant signal repos it seems.
simple remedy. and good reminder to keep an eye on those, if an installation doesn’t work.
thanks for reaching out.
